awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Effects of the Social Environment on DNA Methylation and Immune Function in Primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Many primates, including humans, live in complex social environments, and the capacity to deal with such environments can vary substantially across individuals. While some individuals form stable, positive social bonds, others do not; similarly, individuals vary in their achieved social status. Research in both humans and non-human primates suggests that variation in these social experiences can have profound effects on physiology, health, and survival. This project uses behavioral and biological data from wild baboons to test the hypothesis that social adversity influences health-related traits by altering the way that genes are expressed. Identifying these connections is crucial for understanding the evolution of primate sociality, and for addressing the well-documented health consequences of social adversity in humans. Other broader impacts of the project include fostering of research collaborations, undergraduate training, and dissemination of novel methods for genomic studies. 

This two-year project will study 88 adult male baboons from the Amboseli, Kenya baboon population, to investigate whether low social status and/or social isolation lead to changes in DNA methylation, and whether these changes predict how individuals respond to an immune challenge. To do so, investigators will combine behavioral data with measurements of genome-wide DNA methylation levels and immune-related gene expression patterns. The resulting data will shed new light on whether, and to what degree, social experiences influence immunological traits that likely contribute to health and survival in wild primates.

por.por_cntn:
SUMMARY AND INTELLECTUAL MERIT: The social environment has profound effects on health and survival in both human and nonhuman primates. Low social status, social isolation, and lack of social support can lead to chronic psychosocial stress, which in turn can affect disease susceptibility. However, despite the well-established link between social stress and variation in health and Darwinian fitness-related traits, the mechanisms through which these relationships arise remain poorly understood. We addressed these gaps by (i) testing the relationship between genome-wide DNA methylation (an epigenetic modifier of gene expression levels) and measures of social stress in a wild primate and (ii) determining whether changes in DNA methylation led to altered immune function. We focused our sample collection and analyses on a long-term study population of yellow baboons in Kenya, for whom unusually detailed longitudinal data on social environmental experiences were also available.

            Our results suggest that experiencing multiple early life stressors, including maternal loss, maternal social isolation, and low maternal social status is associated with changes in DNA methylation levels across the baboon genome. Currently, we are refining these estimates by generating data for an additional set of samples, which will give us further power to identify associations between the social environment and the epigenome. Strikingly, we have also discovered that social status in adulthood (measured in baboons as dominance rank) is strongly associated with genome-wide gene expression levels in white blood cells. These effects are especially pronounced in males, such that genes involved in inflammation tend to be more highly expressed in high status males. This pattern may reflect the energetic demands of maintaining high rank and the unique physiological state of high status males, who also heal faster from wounds and maintain distinct steroid hormone profiles compared to low ranking males. Together, our findings provide novel insight into the molecular consequences of variation in social conditions in a wild primate population, and provide context for understanding the social gradients in health observed in humans and captive primates. Our results also highlight specific genes and pathways involved in sensing and responding to social stressors in natural primate groups. Thus, they inform our understanding of how challenges associated with group living and sociality have shaped primate evolution. 

 

BROADER IMPACTS: This project has resulted in five sets of broader impacts. First, it supported outreach to elementary and middle school students in North Carolina, aimed at inspiring their interest in science and pursuit of a possible career in STEM. Specifically, the co-PI participated in the Women and Mathematics Mentoring Program (WAM) during the course of this award, a program that pairs young women with female mentors engaged in scientific careers. In addition, the co-PI participated in a ‘Q & A’ program through a local elementary school, where young students asked scientists about their research and experiences as scientists. Second, the co-PI mentored a female undergraduate student during the course of this project, which culminated in an undergraduate honors thesis. Third, the project promoted training and international collaboration. Specifically, the co-PI and her collaborators worked with a local Kenyan research institution, the Institute of Primate Research (IPR), to generate data related to this project. IPR staff have been integral to the work presented here, and will be included as co-authors on a related manuscript in preparation. Fourth, the co-PI discussed the results of this project with scientific audiences at multiple conferences, workshops, and external seminar series. Finally, this project has resulted in the release of a publicly available software program for analyzing DNA methylation data sets (http://www.xzlab.org/software.html) as well as a freely available R Shiny application for simulation DNA methylation data sets and performing power analyses (http://www.tung-lab.org/protocols-and-software.html). Both applications have facilitated contact and engagement between the co-PI and researchers from many other universities, and has generally added to the tool set available to the ecological and evolutionary epigenomics community.
